conclusion: Initial position of light source is to the left of the objects, casting shadows to the right.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark area on the opposite side of the light source.
The length and direction of the shadow depend on the angle of the light source relative to the object.
When the light source moves to the right, directly above the objects, the angle of light changes.
As the light source moves directly above, the shadows will shift from being cast to the right to being cast directly below the objects.
Shadows will become shorter as the light source moves directly overhead because the angle of incidence becomes more perpendicular to the ground.
Shadow A (from the egg) moves from the right side of the egg to directly below it and becomes shorter.
Shadow B (from the blue object) moves from the right side of the blue object to directly below it and becomes shorter.
Shadow C (from the blue object) moves from the right side of the blue object to directly below it and becomes shorter.
Shadow D (from the blue object) moves from the right side of the blue object to directly below it and becomes shorter.

Final answer: When the light source moves to the right, directly above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will shift from being cast to the right to being cast directly below the objects and will become shorter.
